events.text_segment:
Although they had but that moment left the school behind them, they were now in the busy thoroughfares of a city, where shadowy passengers passed and repassed; where shadowy carts and coaches battled for the way, and all the strife and tumult of a real city were. It was made plain enough, by the dressing of the shops, that here too it was Christmas time again; but it was evening, and the streets were lighted up.
The Ghost stopped at a certain warehouse door, and asked Scrooge if he knew it.
“Know it!” said Scrooge. “Was I apprenticed here!”
They went in. At sight of an old gentleman in a Welsh wig, sitting behind such a high desk, that if he had been two inches taller he must have knocked his head against the ceiling, Scrooge cried in great excitement:
“Why, it’s old Fezziwig! Bless his heart; it’s Fezziwig alive again!”
Old Fezziwig laid down his pen, and looked up at the clock, which pointed to the hour of seven. He rubbed his hands; adjusted his capacious waistcoat; laughed all over himself, from his shoes to his organ of benevolence; and called out in a comfortable, oily, rich, fat, jovial voice:
“Yo ho, there! Ebenezer! Dick!”
Scrooge’s former self, now grown a young man, came briskly in, accompanied by his fellow-’prentice.
“Dick Wilkins, to be sure!” said Scrooge to the Ghost. “Bless me, yes. There he is. He was very much attached to me, was Dick. Poor Dick! Dear, dear!”
“Yo ho, my boys!” said Fezziwig. “No more work to-night. Christmas Eve, Dick. Christmas, Ebenezer! Let’s have the shutters up,” cried old Fezziwig, with a sharp clap of his hands, “before a man can say Jack Robinson!”
You wouldn’t believe how those two fellows went at it! They charged into the street with the shutters—one, two, three—had ’em up in their places—four, five, six—barred ’em and pinned ’em—seven, eight, nine—and came back before you could have got to twelve, panting like race-horses.
“Hilli-ho!” cried old Fezziwig, skipping down from the high desk, with wonderful agility. “Clear away, my lads, and let’s have lots of room here! Hilli-ho, Dick! Chirrup, Ebenezer!”
Clear away! There was nothing they wouldn’t have cleared away, or couldn’t have cleared away, with old Fezziwig looking on. It was done in a minute. Every movable was packed off, as if it were dismissed from public life for evermore; the floor was swept and watered, the lamps were trimmed, fuel was heaped upon the fire; and the warehouse was as snug, and warm, and dry, and bright a ball-room, as you would desire to see upon a winter’s night.
In came a fiddler with a music-book, and went up to the lofty desk, and made an orchestra of it, and tuned like fifty stomach-aches. In came Mrs. Fezziwig, one vast substantial smile. In came the three Miss Fezziwigs, beaming and lovable. In came the six young followers whose hearts they broke. In came all the young men and women employed in the business. In came the housemaid, with her cousin, the baker. In came the cook, with her brother’s particular friend, the milkman. In came the boy from over the way, who was suspected of not having board enough from his master; trying to hide himself behind the girl from next door but one, who was proved to have had her ears pulled by her mistress. In they all came, one after another; some shyly, some boldly, some gracefully, some awkwardly, some pushing, some pulling; in they all came, anyhow and everyhow. Away they all went, twenty couple at once; hands half round and back again the other way; down the middle and up again; round and round in various stages of affectionate grouping; old top couple always turning up in the wrong place; new top couple starting off again, as soon as they got there; all top couples at last, and not a bottom one to help them! When this result was brought about, old Fezziwig, clapping his hands to stop the dance, cried out, “Well done!” and the fiddler plunged his hot face into a pot of porter, especially provided for that purpose. But scorning rest, upon his reappearance, he instantly began again, though there were no dancers yet, as if the other fiddler had been carried home, exhausted, on a shutter, and he were a bran-new man resolved to beat him out of sight, or perish.
There were more dances, and there were forfeits, and more dances, and there was cake, and there was negus, and there was a great piece of Cold Roast, and there was a great piece of Cold Boiled, and there were mince-pies, and plenty of beer. But the great effect of the evening came after the Roast and Boiled, when the fiddler (an artful dog, mind! The sort of man who knew his business better than you or I could have told it him!) struck up “Sir Roger de Coverley.” Then old Fezziwig stood out to dance with Mrs. Fezziwig. Top couple, too; with a good stiff piece of work cut out for them; three or four and twenty pair of partners; people who were not to be trifled with; people who would dance, and had no notion of walking.
But if they had been twice as many—ah, four times—old Fezziwig would have been a match for them, and so would Mrs. Fezziwig. As to her, she was worthy to be his partner in every sense of the term. If that’s not high praise, tell me higher, and I’ll use it. A positive light appeared to issue from Fezziwig’s calves. They shone in every part of the dance like moons. You couldn’t have predicted, at any given time, what would have become of them next. And when old Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig had gone all through the dance; advance and retire, both hands to your partner, bow and curtsey, corkscrew, thread-the-needle, and back again to your place; Fezziwig “cut”—cut so deftly, that he appeared to wink with his legs, and came upon his feet again without a stagger.
When the clock struck eleven, this domestic ball broke up. Mr. and Mrs. Fezziwig took their stations, one on either side of the door, and shaking hands with every person individually as he or she went out, wished him or her a Merry Christmas. When everybody had retired but the two ’prentices, they did the same to them; and thus the cheerful voices died away, and the lads were left to their beds; which were under a counter in the back-shop.
During the whole of this time, Scrooge had acted like a man out of his wits. His heart and soul were in the scene, and with his former self. He corroborated everything, remembered everything, enjoyed everything, and underwent the strangest agitation. It was not until now, when the bright faces of his former self and Dick were turned from them, that he remembered the Ghost, and became conscious that it was looking full upon him, while the light upon its head burnt very clear.
“A small matter,” said the Ghost, “to make these silly folks so full of gratitude.”
“Small!” echoed Scrooge.
The Spirit signed to him to listen to the two apprentices, who were pouring out their hearts in praise of Fezziwig: and when he had done so, said,
“Why! Is it not? He has spent but a few pounds of your mortal money: three or four perhaps. Is that so much that he deserves this praise?”
“It isn’t that,” said Scrooge, heated by the remark, and speaking unconsciously like his former, not his latter, self. “It isn’t that, Spirit. He has the power to render us happy or unhappy; to make our service light or burdensome; a pleasure or a toil. Say that his power lies in words and looks; in things so slight and insignificant that it is impossible to add and count ’em up: what then? The happiness he gives, is quite as great as if it cost a fortune.”
He felt the Spirit’s glance, and stopped.
“What is the matter?” asked the Ghost.
“Nothing particular,” said Scrooge.
“Something, I think?” the Ghost insisted.
“No,” said Scrooge, “No. I should like to be able to say a word or two to my clerk just now. That’s all.”

Although they had but that moment left the school behind them, they were now in the busy thoroughfares of a city, where shadowy passengers passed and repassed; where shadowy carts and coaches battled for the way, and all the strife and tumult of a real city were. The streets were choked with the spectral forms of men and women, their faces indistinct yet filled with the same restless energy that had driven them in life. The air hummed with the echoes of long-forgotten voices—merchants hawking their wares, children laughing, and the occasional cry of a street vendor.  

Scrooge, bewildered, clutched at the Spirit’s robe. "Where are we?" he demanded, his voice trembling.  

The Ghost of Christmas Past turned its luminous gaze upon him. "Do you not recognize it?"  

Scrooge peered closer, his eyes straining against the shifting shadows. Then, with a jolt, he saw it—the familiar curve of a street, the outline of a shop he had known in his youth. "This—this is London," he murmured. "But not as it is now. This is the London of my boyhood!"  

The Spirit inclined its head. "You remember."  

Scrooge did remember. The city of his childhood had been a place of wonder and hardship, of narrow escapes and crushing disappointments. He had walked these very streets as a boy, his pockets empty, his heart full of longing for something he could not name.  

A sudden shout drew his attention. A group of ragged children darted past, their laughter ringing like bells. Among them, Scrooge caught sight of a small, thin boy—a boy with his own face.  

"That’s me," he whispered, his throat tightening.  

The young Scrooge lagged behind the others, his steps slower, his expression solemn. He carried a book beneath his arm, clutching it as though it were a treasure. The other boys called to him, but he shook his head, turning instead toward a dimly lit alley.  

"Where is he going?" Scrooge asked, though he already knew.  

The Spirit did not answer, but followed the boy as he slipped into the shadows. The alley opened into a small courtyard, where a single candle burned in a grimy window. Inside, a man sat hunched over a ledger, his face gaunt, his fingers stained with ink.  

Scrooge’s breath caught. "My father."  

The man looked up as the boy entered, his expression unreadable. For a moment, neither spoke. Then the father returned to his work, and the boy, with a quiet sigh, took his place at the opposite end of the table, opening his book to read.  

Scrooge turned away, unable to bear the sight. "He never loved me," he muttered. "Not truly."  

The Spirit’s voice was gentle. "Is that what you believe?"  

"What else am I to think? He sent me away—kept me at that wretched school even when other boys went home for Christmas!"  

"And yet," the Spirit said, "you returned to him in the end."  

Scrooge had no answer. He watched as the scene shifted—the boy grew taller, his shoulders broader, his eyes harder. The father aged, his back bending beneath the weight of debts and disappointments. And then, one day, the boy was gone, vanished into the city to seek his fortune.  

The Spirit raised its hand, and the vision dissolved into mist. When it cleared, they stood before a different building—a counting-house, its windows bright with lamplight. Inside, a young man sat at a desk, his quill scratching furiously across a page.  

Scrooge recognized himself again, though this version was older, sharper, his mouth set in a firm line. A knock came at the door, and a cheerful voice called out, "Ebenezer! Still working? Come, man, it’s Christmas Eve!"  

The young Scrooge barely glanced up. "I’ve no time for idle celebrations, Fezziwig. There’s money to be made."  

A stout, red-faced man bustled into the room, his arms laden with parcels. "Nonsense! The ledgers can wait. The world won’t end if you take one evening to enjoy yourself."  

Scrooge watched, a pang of regret twisting in his chest. Fezziwig had been kind to him—had treated him like a son. And how had he repaid that kindness? With impatience, with scorn.  

The Spirit turned to him. "Do you remember this night?"  

Scrooge nodded slowly. "I do. Fezziwig insisted I join his family for supper. I went, but I—I resented every moment of it."  

"And why was that?"  

"Because I thought it a waste of time. Because I believed happiness was something to be earned, not given."

Scrooge’s heart lurched. "Belle."  

She was as beautiful as he remembered—her dark hair coiled neatly, her eyes soft with sorrow. The door opened, and his younger self entered, his expression cold.  

"Ebenezer," she said, rising to meet him. "I’ve been waiting."  

"I’ve been busy," he replied.  

She hesitated, then took a deep breath. "I cannot do this any longer."  

"Do what?"

His younger self stiffened. "I provide for you, don’t I? What more do you want?"

The Ghost’s voice was sorrowful. "You asked to see the past, Ebenezer Scrooge. These are the shadows of things that have been. They cannot be changed."  

Scrooge covered his face with his hands. "Then take me away. I cannot bear it."  

The Spirit laid a gentle hand upon his shoulder, and the world dissolved into darkness once more.

events.title: Belle Ends Her Engagement to Scrooge
detailed_summary: As Scrooge voices his wish regarding his clerk, his former self dims the lamps, and he finds himself beside the Ghost in the open air again.
The Spirit announces its time is short and urges haste.
The scene changes, showing Scrooge again, but older, in his prime, his face beginning to show lines of care and avarice, with a greedy look in his eye.
He is not alone; a fair young woman named Belle, wearing mourning clothes, sits beside him with tears in her eyes.
Belle softly tells him that another idol, a golden one, has replaced her in his heart.
She states she has no cause to grieve if this new idol can comfort him as she would have tried to.
Scrooge asks what idol she means, and she confirms it is gold.
He defends his pursuit of wealth as a reaction against the world's harshness towards poverty.
Belle gently counters that he fears the world too much, and all his hopes have merged into acquiring wealth, letting his nobler aspirations die.
Scrooge retorts defensively, questioning if becoming wiser means he has changed towards her.
Belle shakes her head, asserting that he has changed significantly since their engagement, which was made when they were both poor and content.
She argues that what promised happiness then is now fraught with misery because they are fundamentally different people.
She asks rhetorically if he has ever sought release from their engagement.

When he asks how, she explains his release was sought not in words, but in his changed nature, altered spirit, different life focus, and the shift in his ultimate hope towards Gain, which devalued her love in his eyes.
She challenges him: if they were unattached, would he seek out and try to win her, a dowerless girl, now?
Scrooge seems to concede the point but struggles, saying, "You think not."

Belle affirms she knows he wouldn't choose her now, or if he did momentarily betray his principle of Gain, regret would follow; therefore, she releases him with a full heart, for the love of the man he used to be.
As he is about to speak, she turns away and continues.
She hopes he might feel brief pain from this memory but predicts he will quickly dismiss it as an unprofitable dream.
She wishes him happiness in his chosen life and departs.

events.text_segment:
His former self turned down the lamps as he gave utterance to the wish; and Scrooge and the Ghost again stood side by side in the open air.
“My time grows short,” observed the Spirit. “Quick!”
This was not addressed to Scrooge, or to any one whom he could see, but it produced an immediate effect. For again Scrooge saw himself. He was older now; a man in the prime of life. His face had not the harsh and rigid lines of later years; but it had begun to wear the signs of care and avarice. There was an eager, greedy, restless motion in the eye, which showed the passion that had taken root, and where the shadow of the growing tree would fall.
He was not alone, but sat by the side of a fair young girl in a mourning-dress: in whose eyes there were tears, which sparkled in the light that shone out of the Ghost of Christmas Past.
“It matters little,” she said, softly. “To you, very little. Another idol has displaced me; and if it can cheer and comfort you in time to come, as I would have tried to do, I have no just cause to grieve.”
“What Idol has displaced you?” he rejoined.
“A golden one.”
“This is the even-handed dealing of the world!” he said. “There is nothing on which it is so hard as poverty; and there is nothing it professes to condemn with such severity as the pursuit of wealth!”
“You fear the world too much,” she answered, gently. “All your other hopes have merged into the hope of being beyond the chance of its sordid reproach. I have seen your nobler aspirations fall off one by one, until the master-passion, Gain, engrosses you. Have I not?”
“What then?” he retorted. “Even if I have grown so much wiser, what then? I am not changed towards you.”
She shook her head.
“Am I?”
“Our contract is an old one. It was made when we were both poor and content to be so, until, in good season, we could improve our worldly fortune by our patient industry. You are changed. When it was made, you were another man.”
“I was a boy,” he said impatiently.
“Your own feeling tells you that you were not what you are,” she returned. “I am. That which promised happiness when we were one in heart, is fraught with misery now that we are two. How often and how keenly I have thought of this, I will not say. It is enough that I have thought of it, and can release you.”
“Have I ever sought release?”
“In words. No. Never.”
“In what, then?”
“In a changed nature; in an altered spirit; in another atmosphere of life; another Hope as its great end. In everything that made my love of any worth or value in your sight. If this had never been between us,” said the girl, looking mildly, but with steadiness, upon him; “tell me, would you seek me out and try to win me now? Ah, no!”
He seemed to yield to the justice of this supposition, in spite of himself. But he said with a struggle, “You think not.”
“I would gladly think otherwise if I could,” she answered, “Heaven knows! When I have learned a Truth like this, I know how strong and irresistible it must be. But if you were free to-day, to-morrow, yesterday, can even I believe that you would choose a dowerless girl—you who, in your very confidence with her, weigh everything by Gain: or, choosing her, if for a moment you were false enough to your one guiding principle to do so, do I not know that your repentance and regret would surely follow? I do; and I release you. With a full heart, for the love of him you once were.”
He was about to speak; but with her head turned from him, she resumed.
“You may—the memory of what is past half makes me hope you will—have pain in this. A very, very brief time, and you will dismiss the recollection of it, gladly, as an unprofitable dream, from which it happened well that you awoke. May you be happy in the life you have chosen!”
She left him, and they parted.

Scrooge’s hands clenched into fists. “I—I never meant—”  

“But you did,” the Ghost interrupted. “Every harsh word, every withheld kindness, every coin clutched tight in your fist—they have all led to this.”

The Ghost’s expression softened, but its words were firm. “Time is fleeting, Ebenezer Scrooge. The future is not yet written, but the path you are on leads only to darkness.”

“One shadow more!” exclaimed the Ghost.

But the relentless Ghost pinioned him in both his arms, and forced him to observe what happened next.
They were in another scene and place; a room, not very large or handsome, but full of comfort. Near to the winter fire sat a beautiful young girl, so like that last that Scrooge believed it was the same, until he saw her, now a comely matron, sitting opposite her daughter. The noise in this room was perfectly tumultuous, for there were more children there, than Scrooge in his agitated state of mind could count; and, unlike the celebrated herd in the poem, they were not forty children conducting themselves like one, but every child was conducting itself like forty. The consequences were uproarious beyond belief; but no one seemed to care; on the contrary, the mother and daughter laughed heartily, and enjoyed it very much; and the latter, soon beginning to mingle in the sports, got pillaged by the young brigands most ruthlessly. What would I not have given to be one of them! Though I never could have been so rude, no, no! I wouldn’t for the wealth of all the world have crushed that braided hair, and torn it down; and for the precious little shoe, I wouldn’t have plucked it off, God bless my soul! to save my life. As to measuring her waist in sport, as they did, bold young brood, I couldn’t have done it; I should have expected my arm to have grown round it for a punishment, and never come straight again. And yet I should have dearly liked, I own, to have touched her lips; to have questioned her, that she might have opened them; to have looked upon the lashes of her downcast eyes, and never raised a blush; to have let loose waves of hair, an inch of which would be a keepsake beyond price: in short, I should have liked, I do confess, to have had the lightest licence of a child, and yet to have been man enough to know its value.
But now a knocking at the door was heard, and such a rush immediately ensued that she with laughing face and plundered dress was borne towards it the centre of a flushed and boisterous group, just in time to greet the father, who came home attended by a man laden with Christmas toys and presents. Then the shouting and the struggling, and the onslaught that was made on the defenceless porter! The scaling him with chairs for ladders to dive into his pockets, despoil him of brown-paper parcels, hold on tight by his cravat, hug him round his neck, pommel his back, and kick his legs in irrepressible affection! The shouts of wonder and delight with which the development of every package was received! The terrible announcement that the baby had been taken in the act of putting a doll’s frying-pan into his mouth, and was more than suspected of having swallowed a fictitious turkey, glued on a wooden platter! The immense relief of finding this a false alarm! The joy, and gratitude, and ecstasy! They are all indescribable alike. It is enough that by degrees the children and their emotions got out of the parlour, and by one stair at a time, up to the top of the house; where they went to bed, and so subsided.
And now Scrooge looked on more attentively than ever, when the master of the house, having his daughter leaning fondly on him, sat down with her and her mother at his own fireside; and when he thought that such another creature, quite as graceful and as full of promise, might have called him father, and been a spring-time in the haggard winter of his life, his sight grew very dim indeed.
“Belle,” said the husband, turning to his wife with a smile, “I saw an old friend of yours this afternoon.”
“Who was it?”
“Guess!”
“How can I? Tut, don’t I know?” she added in the same breath, laughing as he laughed. “Mr. Scrooge.”
“Mr. Scrooge it was. I passed his office window; and as it was not shut up, and he had a candle inside, I could scarcely help seeing him. His partner lies upon the point of death, I hear; and there he sat alone. Quite alone in the world, I do believe.”
“Spirit!” said Scrooge in a broken voice, “remove me from this place.”
“I told you these were shadows of the things that have been,” said the Ghost. “That they are what they are, do not blame me!”
“Remove me!” Scrooge exclaimed, “I cannot bear it!”
He turned upon the Ghost, and seeing that it looked upon him with a face, in which in some strange way there were fragments of all the faces it had shown him, wrestled with it.
“Leave me! Take me back. Haunt me no longer!”
In the struggle, if that can be called a struggle in which the Ghost with no visible resistance on its own part was undisturbed by any effort of its adversary, Scrooge observed that its light was burning high and bright; and dimly connecting that with its influence over him, he seized the extinguisher-cap, and by a sudden action pressed it down upon its head.
The Spirit dropped beneath it, so that the extinguisher covered its whole form; but though Scrooge pressed it down with all his force, he could not hide the light: which streamed from under it, in an unbroken flood upon the ground.
He was conscious of being exhausted, and overcome by an irresistible drowsiness; and, further, of being in his own bedroom. He gave the cap a parting squeeze, in which his hand relaxed; and had barely time to reel to bed, before he sank into a heavy sleep.

The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come remained silent, its spectral hand still outstretched, pointing toward the grim scene before them. Scrooge recoiled, his face ashen, his breath ragged. The vision of his own neglected grave, overgrown with weeds and untended by any mourner, had struck him like a physical blow.  

“Have I not seen enough?” Scrooge cried, his voice breaking. “Must I witness the indifference of the world to my passing? The debtors laughing at my death, the pawnbroker’s den where my very bed-curtains are sold for a pittance? Oh, Spirit, if there is any lesson in this, let me learn it now! I am not the man I was—I will not be the man whose shadow you have shown me!”  

The phantom did not answer. Instead, it raised its hand once more, and the mist swirled around them, dissolving the graveyard into darkness. Scrooge felt himself lifted, the cold wind rushing past his ears, until suddenly—he was standing in a familiar place. His own bedchamber. The fire had dwindled to embers, the room silent save for the ticking of the clock.  

The Ghost stood beside him, its presence as oppressive as ever. Scrooge turned to it, his hands clasped in desperate supplication. “Tell me, Spirit,” he whispered, “are these the shadows of the things that *will* be, or are they shadows of the things that *may* be only?”  

Still, the specter gave no reply.  

Scrooge’s gaze fell upon his own bed, and with a shudder, he recalled the vision of his lifeless body lying there, stripped of dignity, of love, of all human warmth. “No,” he gasped. “No, I will not let it be so! I will honor Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it all the year! I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future! The spirits of all three shall strive within me! I will not shut out the lessons that they teach!”  

As he spoke, the Ghost’s hooded form seemed to waver, its outline growing fainter. The room brightened, the first pale light of dawn creeping through the window. Scrooge blinked—and the phantom was gone.  

For a moment, he stood frozen, his heart pounding. Then, with a sudden burst of joy, he rushed to the window and threw it open. The crisp morning air rushed in, and the sound of church bells filled the sky.  

“It’s Christmas Day!” Scrooge exclaimed, laughing like a child. “I haven’t missed it! The spirits have done it all in one night!” He clapped his hands together, scarcely able to contain his delight. “I’m as light as a feather, as happy as an angel, as merry as a schoolboy!”  

He dressed in such haste that he nearly tumbled down the stairs in his eagerness. Below, the streets were alive with activity—carolers singing, children playing, vendors calling out their wares. Scrooge, who had once scowled at such noise, now beamed at every passerby.  

“You there, boy!” he called to a lad lingering near the bakery. “What day is it?”  

“Why, it’s Christmas, sir!” the boy replied, puzzled.  

“A merry Christmas to you!” Scrooge said, pressing a handful of coins into the child’s palm. “Now, tell me—do you know the prize turkey hanging in the poulterer’s window?”  

“The big one, sir? Twice the size of me?”

events.title: Anticipation and Arrival of the Second Spirit
detailed_summary: Scrooge awakens exactly at one o'clock, fully conscious and prepared for his pre-arranged meeting with the second spirit.
Feeling uneasy about where the ghost might emerge, he takes the initiative to pull aside all his bed curtains himself and lies down, keeping watch.
The narrator emphasizes Scrooge's readiness for a wide range of strange phenomena, suggesting almost nothing could greatly surprise him.
However, when the clock strikes one and no spirit appears, Scrooge is unexpectedly overcome by intense trembling.
Minutes pass with no apparition, while Scrooge remains lying in bed, illuminated by a strong reddish light flooding his room from the adjacent chamber.
This unexplained light proves more unnerving than ghosts, as Scrooge cannot discern its source or purpose, even briefly fearing he might be undergoing spontaneous combustion.
Finally, he reasons that the light must originate from the next room and cautiously approaches the door.
Just as his hand reaches the lock, an unfamiliar voice distinctly calls him by name and instructs him to enter.
He obeys and finds himself in his own room, yet it has undergone a dramatic and festive transformation.
The walls and ceiling are entirely covered with living greenery—holly, mistletoe, and ivy—making it resemble a grove, with gleaming berries sparkling everywhere.
A massive fire blazes in the hearth, far grander than Scrooge or Marley ever had.

All this time, he lay upon his bed, the very core and centre of a blaze of ruddy light, which streamed upon it when the clock proclaimed the hour; and which, being only light, was more alarming than a dozen ghosts, as he was powerless to make out what it meant, or would be at; and was sometimes apprehensive that he might be at that very moment an interesting case of spontaneous combustion, without having the consolation of knowing it. Awaking in the middle of a prodigiously tough snore, and sitting up in bed to get his thoughts together, Scrooge had no occasion to be told that the bell was again upon the stroke of One. He felt the truth of it before the sound had ceased to vibrate in the heavy air of the chamber. The curtains of his bed were drawn aside—not by his own hand, nor by any visible presence—and there, before him, stood another spectral figure, draped in a deep black garment that concealed its head, its face, its form, leaving nothing visible save one outstretched hand.  

For a moment, Scrooge lay still, his breath shallow, his heart pounding like a prisoner’s against the bars of his ribs. The figure neither moved nor spoke, yet its very silence was more dreadful than any words. The air grew colder, and Scrooge’s own breath curled before him in pale, trembling wisps.  

“Are you the Spirit whose coming was foretold to me?” asked Scrooge.  

The figure answered not, but pointed onward with its hand.  

“You are about to show me shadows of things that have not happened, but will happen in the time before us,” Scrooge pursued. “Is that so, Spirit?”  

The hooded head inclined slightly, as if in assent, and still the hand remained extended.  

Scrooge shuddered. The silence of the specter was more terrible than any voice. He knew, with a creeping certainty, that this was the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come—the last of the spirits who would visit him. And though he could not see its face, he felt its gaze upon him, heavy as a tombstone.  

“Lead on, then,” said Scrooge, clambering from his bed with unsteady limbs. “The night is waning fast, and I know your time is precious. Lead on!”  

No sooner had he spoken than the room dissolved around him, and he found himself standing in the heart of London, though the city was strangely altered. The streets were the same, the buildings familiar, yet an air of grim indifference hung over all. People hurried past one another without greeting, their faces pinched with care or twisted in greed. The shops displayed their wares, but no laughter rang from the taverns, no carols lifted from the churches. It was Christmas, yet no one seemed to remember it.  

Scrooge turned to the Spirit, bewildered. “Is this what is to come? Have men forgotten the meaning of this day?”  

The Spirit said nothing, only glided forward, forcing Scrooge to follow. They passed through the bustling streets like shadows, unseen and unheard, until they came to a wretched alley where a group of ragged children huddled for warmth. Their faces were gaunt, their eyes hollow, and as Scrooge looked upon them, a terrible recognition seized him.  

“Spirit,” he whispered, “these children—they are Ignorance and Want, are they not?”  

The Spirit’s hidden gaze seemed to bore into him, and Scrooge recoiled as if struck. He had seen these children before, in the arms of the Ghost of Christmas Present, but now they were grown larger, more desperate, their misery unchecked.  

“Are there no prisons?” Scrooge muttered, echoing his own cruel words from years past. “No workhouses?”  

The Spirit’s silence was accusation enough.  

On they went, through scenes of sorrow and neglect, until at last they paused before a churchyard, its iron gates rusted, its headstones leaning like broken teeth. The Spirit pointed to a freshly dug grave, and Scrooge, with a creeping dread, approached it. The stone was unmarked, the earth still loose.  

“Before I draw nearer to that stone,” said Scrooge, his voice trembling, “answer me one question. Are these the shadows of the things that *will* be, or are they shadows of the things that *may* be only?”  

Still, the Spirit did not speak, but its outstretched hand moved inexorably toward the grave.  

Scrooge’s knees gave way. “No, Spirit! Oh, no, no!” He clutched at the specter’s robe. “Tell me that I may yet change these shadows! That this future is not set in stone!”  

For the first time, the Ghost seemed to hesitate. Then, slowly, it lowered its hand.  

And Scrooge awoke—gasping, sweating, clutching at his own bedclothes—to find himself in his own room, in his own bed, with the golden light of Christmas morning streaming through the window.  

He was alive. He had time. And with a heart bursting with newfound joy, Ebenezer Scrooge resolved to keep the lessons of the spirits alive in him forever.

events.title: Meeting the Ghost of Christmas Present
detailed_summary: The Giant figure warmly invites Scrooge to enter the room and become better acquainted.
Scrooge steps inside timidly, his usual defiance replaced by humility, and he avoids meeting the Spirit's kind gaze.
The Spirit identifies himself as the Ghost of Christmas Present and commands Scrooge to look upon him.
Scrooge observes the Spirit's attire: a simple green robe bordered with white fur, worn loosely, revealing a bare chest.
The Spirit's feet are also bare, and his head is adorned only with a holly wreath accented with shining icicles.
His appearance is characterized by long, free dark brown curls, a genial face, sparkling eyes, an open hand, a cheerful voice, and an unconstrained, joyful manner.
An antique, empty, rust-eaten scabbard hangs at his waist.
The Spirit confirms that Scrooge has never encountered a being like him before.
He inquires if Scrooge has ever journeyed with any of his 'elder brothers' - the Ghosts of Christmas Present from previous years, explaining he himself is very young.
Scrooge admits he likely has not and asks if the Spirit has numerous brothers.
The Ghost reveals he has had 'more than eighteen hundred' brothers.
Scrooge quietly reflects on the immense responsibility of providing for such a vast family.

events.text_segment:
“Come in!” exclaimed the Ghost. “Come in! and know me better, man!”
Scrooge entered timidly, and hung his head before this Spirit. He was not the dogged Scrooge he had been; and though the Spirit’s eyes were clear and kind, he did not like to meet them.
“I am the Ghost of Christmas Present,” said the Spirit. “Look upon me!”
Scrooge reverently did so. It was clothed in one simple green robe, or mantle, bordered with white fur. This garment hung so loosely on the figure, that its capacious breast was bare, as if disdaining to be warded or concealed by any artifice. Its feet, observable beneath the ample folds of the garment, were also bare; and on its head it wore no other covering than a holly wreath, set here and there with shining icicles. Its dark brown curls were long and free; free as its genial face, its sparkling eye, its open hand, its cheery voice, its unconstrained demeanour, and its joyful air. Girded round its middle was an antique scabbard; but no sword was in it, and the ancient sheath was eaten up with rust.
“You have never seen the like of me before!” exclaimed the Spirit.
“Never,” Scrooge made answer to it.
“Have never walked forth with the younger members of my family; meaning (for I am very young) my elder brothers born in these later years?” pursued the Phantom.
“I don’t think I have,” said Scrooge. “I am afraid I have not. Have you had many brothers, Spirit?”
“More than eighteen hundred,” said the Ghost.
“A tremendous family to provide for!” muttered Scrooge.

events.text_segment:
The Ghost of Christmas Present rose.
“Spirit,” said Scrooge submissively, “conduct me where you will. I went forth last night on compulsion, and I learnt a lesson which is working now. To-night, if you have aught to teach me, let me profit by it.”
“Touch my robe!”
Scrooge did as he was told, and held it fast.
Holly, mistletoe, red berries, ivy, turkeys, geese, game, poultry, brawn, meat, pigs, sausages, oysters, pies, puddings, fruit, and punch, all vanished instantly. So did the room, the fire, the ruddy glow, the hour of night, and they stood in the city streets on Christmas morning, where (for the weather was severe) the people made a rough, but brisk and not unpleasant kind of music, in scraping the snow from the pavement in front of their dwellings, and from the tops of their houses, whence it was mad delight to the boys to see it come plumping down into the road below, and splitting into artificial little snow-storms.
The house fronts looked black enough, and the windows blacker, contrasting with the smooth white sheet of snow upon the roofs, and with the dirtier snow upon the ground; which last deposit had been ploughed up in deep furrows by the heavy wheels of carts and waggons; furrows that crossed and re-crossed each other hundreds of times where the great streets branched off; and made intricate channels, hard to trace in the thick yellow mud and icy water. The sky was gloomy, and the shortest streets were choked up with a dingy mist, half thawed, half frozen, whose heavier particles descended in a shower of sooty atoms, as if all the chimneys in Great Britain had, by one consent, caught fire, and were blazing away to their dear hearts’ content.

detailed_summary: Despite the grim weather and urban setting, an pervasive atmosphere of cheerfulness exists, surpassing even the brightest summer day.
People clearing snow exchange jovial calls and good-natured snowballs.
Shops like poulterers' and fruiterers' remain partially open, displaying their wares radiantly: abundant chestnuts, onions, pears, apples, grapes, nuts, and citrus fruits, tempting passersby.
Even goldfish in bowls seem stirred by the festive energy.
Grocers' shops, though nearly closed, emanate warmth and bustle with merry sounds, brisk service, enticing smells of tea and coffee, and displays of holiday foods.
Customers, caught up in the day's hopeful excitement, rush about good-humoredly, bumping into each other and making comical errors, while the grocer and staff embody openness and warmth.
Church bells summon well-dressed, cheerful crowds to services.
Simultaneously, countless poorer people emerge from side streets, carrying their dinners to be cooked at local bakeries.
The Spirit observes these poorer revellers with keen interest, standing with Scrooge near a baker's doorway.
As they pass, he lifts the covers from their meals and sprinkles a type of incense from his torch onto their food.

This torch possesses a unique power: when sprinkled on dinner-carriers who argue after jostling each other, it instantly restores their good humour, reminding them it's shameful to quarrel on Christmas Day.
Scrooge asks about the torch's sprinkle; the Spirit confirms it carries his 'own' flavour, best applied to kindly given meals, especially those of the poor 'because it needs it most.'

Scrooge then challenges the Spirit, questioning why beings like him would endorse actions (like Sunday closures of businesses, including bakeries) that restrict the poor's few opportunities for enjoyment.
The Spirit strongly denies advocating such measures.
Scrooge clarifies that such actions have been taken 'in your name, or at least in that of your family.'

The Spirit passionately refutes this, stating that humans who commit acts driven by negative passions like pride, ill-will, and selfishness in the name of Christmas are utterly alien to him and his kin; their actions should be blamed on themselves alone.

There was nothing very cheerful in the climate or the town, and yet was there an air of cheerfulness abroad that the clearest summer air and brightest summer sun might have endeavoured to diffuse in vain.
For, the people who were shovelling away on the housetops were jovial and full of glee; calling out to one another from the parapets, and now and then exchanging a facetious snowball—better-natured missile far than many a wordy jest—laughing heartily if it went right and not less heartily if it went wrong. The poulterers’ shops were still half open, and the fruiterers’ were radiant in their glory. There were great, round, pot-bellied baskets of chestnuts, shaped like the waistcoats of jolly old gentlemen, lolling at the doors, and tumbling out into the street in their apoplectic opulence. There were ruddy, brown-faced, broad-girthed Spanish Onions, shining in the fatness of their growth like Spanish Friars, and winking from their shelves in wanton slyness at the girls as they went by, and glanced demurely at the hung-up mistletoe. There were pears and apples, clustered high in blooming pyramids; there were bunches of grapes, made, in the shopkeepers’ benevolence to dangle from conspicuous hooks, that people’s mouths might water gratis as they passed; there were piles of filberts, mossy and brown, recalling, in their fragrance, ancient walks among the woods, and pleasant shufflings ankle deep through withered leaves; there were Norfolk Biffins, squat and swarthy, setting off the yellow of the oranges and lemons, and, in the great compactness of their juicy persons, urgently entreating and beseeching to be carried home in paper bags and eaten after dinner. The very gold and silver fish, set forth among these choice fruits in a bowl, though members of a dull and stagnant-blooded race, appeared to know that there was something going on; and, to a fish, went gasping round and round their little world in slow and passionless excitement.
The Grocers’! oh, the Grocers’! nearly closed, with perhaps two shutters down, or one; but through those gaps such glimpses! It was not alone that the scales descending on the counter made a merry sound, or that the twine and roller parted company so briskly, or that the canisters were rattled up and down like juggling tricks, or even that the blended scents of tea and coffee were so grateful to the nose, or even that the raisins were so plentiful and rare, the almonds so extremely white, the sticks of cinnamon so long and straight, the other spices so delicious, the candied fruits so caked and spotted with molten sugar as to make the coldest lookers-on feel faint and subsequently bilious. Nor was it that the figs were moist and pulpy, or that the French plums blushed in modest tartness from their highly-decorated boxes, or that everything was good to eat and in its Christmas dress; but the customers were all so hurried and so eager in the hopeful promise of the day, that they tumbled up against each other at the door, crashing their wicker baskets wildly, and left their purchases upon the counter, and came running back to fetch them, and committed hundreds of the like mistakes, in the best humour possible; while the Grocer and his people were so frank and fresh that the polished hearts with which they fastened their aprons behind might have been their own, worn outside for general inspection, and for Christmas daws to peck at if they chose.
But soon the steeples called good people all, to church and chapel, and away they came, flocking through the streets in their best clothes, and with their gayest faces. And at the same time there emerged from scores of bye-streets, lanes, and nameless turnings, innumerable people, carrying their dinners to the bakers’ shops. The sight of these poor revellers appeared to interest the Spirit very much, for he stood with Scrooge beside him in a baker’s doorway, and taking off the covers as their bearers passed, sprinkled incense on their dinners from his torch. And it was a very uncommon kind of torch, for once or twice when there were angry words between some dinner-carriers who had jostled each other, he shed a few drops of water on them from it, and their good humour was restored directly. For they said, it was a shame to quarrel upon Christmas Day. And so it was! God love it, so it was!
In time the bells ceased, and the bakers were shut up; and yet there was a genial shadowing forth of all these dinners and the progress of their cooking, in the thawed blotch of wet above each baker’s oven; where the pavement smoked as if its stones were cooking too.
“Is there a peculiar flavour in what you sprinkle from your torch?” asked Scrooge.
“There is. My own.”
“Would it apply to any kind of dinner on this day?” asked Scrooge.
“To any kindly given. To a poor one most.”
“Why to a poor one most?” asked Scrooge.
“Because it needs it most.”
“Spirit,” said Scrooge, after a moment’s thought, “I wonder you, of all the beings in the many worlds about us, should desire to cramp these people’s opportunities of innocent enjoyment.”
“I!” cried the Spirit.
“You would deprive them of their means of dining every seventh day, often the only day on which they can be said to dine at all,” said Scrooge. “Wouldn’t you?”
“I!” cried the Spirit.
“You seek to close these places on the Seventh Day?” said Scrooge. “And it comes to the same thing.”
“I seek!” exclaimed the Spirit.
“Forgive me if I am wrong. It has been done in your name, or at least in that of your family,” said Scrooge.
“There are some upon this earth of yours,” returned the Spirit, “who lay claim to know us, and who do their deeds of passion, pride, ill-will, hatred, envy, bigotry, and selfishness in our name, who are as strange to us and all our kith and kin, as if they had never lived. Remember that, and charge their doings on themselves, not us.”

events.title: The Cratchit Family Christmas - Part 1: Arrival and Dinner Prep
detailed_summary: Scrooge affirms he will remember the Spirit's words, and they proceed invisibly towards the city's suburbs.
Scrooge marvels at the Ghost's ability to adapt his massive size to any space gracefully.
Driven perhaps by kindness, sympathy for the poor, or a desire to display his power, the Spirit leads Scrooge directly to Bob Cratchit's home.
At the threshold, the Spirit smiles and blesses the humble four-room dwelling with his torch, despite Bob's meager weekly wage of fifteen shillings.
Inside, Mrs. Cratchit, wearing a worn but ribbon-adorned gown, prepares the table with her daughter Belinda.
Master Peter Cratchit checks the boiling potatoes, feeling proud in his oversized hand-me-down collar, which hinders him slightly.

Scrooge promised that he would; and they went on, invisible, as they had been before, into the suburbs of the town. The streets grew narrower, the houses more humble, and the air thick with the scent of coal fires and damp earth. Yet, despite the poverty that clung to the place like a shadow, there was a warmth here—a sense of life and community that Scrooge had long forgotten.  

The Ghost of Christmas Present led him to a small, crooked house where the windows glowed with a golden light. Inside, a family gathered around a meager fire, their faces alight with joy despite their circumstances. A woman stirred a pot over the flames, while children laughed and played upon the floor. A man, worn from labor but smiling, lifted a tiny child onto his knee.  

"Do you know this place?" the Spirit asked.  

Scrooge peered through the window, his breath fogging the glass. "No," he admitted, though something tugged at his memory.  

"Look closer," the Ghost urged.  

And then Scrooge saw him—Bob Cratchit, his own clerk, sitting at the table, his threadbare coat hanging by the door. The man who had shivered in his office that very morning, who had dared to ask for a single day’s rest, now sat surrounded by his family, his face glowing with happiness.  

"Tiny Tim!" one of the children cried, and the little boy, frail but bright-eyed, hobbled forward on his crutch.  

Scrooge’s heart clenched. He had seen the boy before, lingering outside his counting-house, waiting for his father. But he had never truly *seen* him—not until now.  

"Spirit," Scrooge whispered, "tell me if Tiny Tim will live."  

The Ghost’s eyes darkened. "I see a vacant seat by the fire," he said softly, "and a crutch without an owner, carefully preserved. If these shadows remain unaltered by the future, the child will die."  

Scrooge’s breath caught. "No," he pleaded. "Say he will be spared!"  

But the Spirit only echoed his own words back to him: *"If he be like to die, he had better do it, and decrease the surplus population."*  

Scrooge bent his head in shame. The words, once so coldly spoken, now burned like a brand upon his soul.  

The Ghost then raised his hand, and the scene shifted. They stood now in a bustling marketplace, where vendors hawked their wares and people hurried to and fro, their arms laden with parcels. The air was rich with the scent of roasting chestnuts and spiced wine, and laughter rang out on every side.  

Scrooge watched as a man, ruddy-faced and jovial, clapped another on the back. "A merry Christmas to you, Fred!"  

Fred—Scrooge’s nephew. The young man who had come to his office that very day, offering goodwill, only to be met with scorn.  

"Uncle Scrooge!" Fred laughed, shaking his head. "He said Christmas was a humbug, as if I didn’t know it already! But I mean to give him the same toast every year, whether he likes it or not."  

The guests around him chuckled, and Scrooge felt an unfamiliar pang—not of irritation, but of longing. These people, so full of warmth, spoke of him not with malice, but with pity. And that, somehow, was worse.  

The Ghost turned to him. "Do you see now? The world moves on without you, Ebenezer Scrooge. It laughs, it loves, it celebrates—with or without your permission."  

Scrooge swallowed hard. "I did not know," he murmured.  

"Or you chose not to see," the Spirit corrected.  

They traveled on, through homes and streets, witnessing scenes of joy and sorrow, of feasting and want. Everywhere, the Spirit’s presence seemed to bless the humble and cast light upon the forgotten. But as the night wore on, Scrooge noticed a change in his guide. The Ghost’s vibrant robes grew dull, his face more careworn.  

"Spirit," Scrooge ventured, "are you well?"  

The Ghost sighed. "My time upon this earth is brief. A mere day—twelve hours—to spread what cheer I may. And now, it nears its end."  

As he spoke, the clock in the distance struck midnight, and from beneath the Spirit’s robe emerged two wretched children—a boy and a girl—their faces gaunt, their eyes hollow.  

"Who are these?" Scrooge recoiled.  

"They are Man’s," the Ghost replied grimly. "This boy is Ignorance. This girl is Want. Beware them both, but most of all beware this boy, for on his brow I see that written which is Doom, unless the writing be erased."  

Scrooge shuddered. "Have they no refuge, no resource?"  

"Are there no prisons?" the Spirit echoed bitterly. "Are there no workhouses?"  

The words struck Scrooge like a blow. His own callousness, thrown back at him. Before he could speak again, the Ghost’s form began to fade, his light dimming like a dying ember.  

"Wait!" Scrooge cried. "Tell me—what must I do?"  

But the Ghost was gone, leaving only the echo of his warning in the cold night air.  

And then—silence.  

Scrooge stood alone in the darkness, his heart pounding. The visions had shaken him to his core. But the night was not yet over. For even now, a new presence approached—a Phantom, draped in black, its face hidden, its bony finger pointing toward the unknown.  

The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come had arrived.

events.text_segment:
Such a bustle ensued that you might have thought a goose the rarest of all birds; a feathered phenomenon, to which a black swan was a matter of course—and in truth it was something very like it in that house. Mrs. Cratchit made the gravy (ready beforehand in a little saucepan) hissing hot; Master Peter mashed the potatoes with incredible vigour; Miss Belinda sweetened up the apple-sauce; Martha dusted the hot plates; Bob took Tiny Tim beside him in a tiny corner at the table; the two young Cratchits set chairs for everybody, not forgetting themselves, and mounting guard upon their posts, crammed spoons into their mouths, lest they should shriek for goose before their turn came to be helped. At last the dishes were set on, and grace was said. It was succeeded by a breathless pause, as Mrs. Cratchit, looking slowly all along the carving-knife, prepared to plunge it in the breast; but when she did, and when the long expected gush of stuffing issued forth, one murmur of delight arose all round the board, and even Tiny Tim, excited by the two young Cratchits, beat on the table with the handle of his knife, and feebly cried Hurrah!
There never was such a goose. Bob said he didn’t believe there ever was such a goose cooked. Its tenderness and flavour, size and cheapness, were the themes of universal admiration. Eked out by apple-sauce and mashed potatoes, it was a sufficient dinner for the whole family; indeed, as Mrs. Cratchit said with great delight (surveying one small atom of a bone upon the dish), they hadn’t ate it all at last! Yet every one had had enough, and the youngest Cratchits in particular, were steeped in sage and onion to the eyebrows! But now, the plates being changed by Miss Belinda, Mrs. Cratchit left the room alone—too nervous to bear witnesses—to take the pudding up and bring it in.
Suppose it should not be done enough! Suppose it should break in turning out! Suppose somebody should have got over the wall of the back-yard, and stolen it, while they were merry with the goose—a supposition at which the two young Cratchits became livid! All sorts of horrors were supposed.
Hallo! A great deal of steam! The pudding was out of the copper. A smell like a washing-day! That was the cloth. A smell like an eating-house and a pastrycook’s next door to each other, with a laundress’s next door to that! That was the pudding! In half a minute Mrs. Cratchit entered—flushed, but smiling proudly—with the pudding, like a speckled cannon-ball, so hard and firm, blazing in half of half-a-quartern of ignited brandy, and bedight with Christmas holly stuck into the top.
Oh, a wonderful pudding! Bob Cratchit said, and calmly too, that he regarded it as the greatest success achieved by Mrs. Cratchit since their marriage. Mrs. Cratchit said that now the weight was off her mind, she would confess she had had her doubts about the quantity of flour. Everybody had something to say about it, but nobody said or thought it was at all a small pudding for a large family. It would have been flat heresy to do so. Any Cratchit would have blushed to hint at such a thing.
At last the dinner was all done, the cloth was cleared, the hearth swept, and the fire made up. The compound in the jug being tasted, and considered perfect, apples and oranges were put upon the table, and a shovel-full of chestnuts on the fire. Then all the Cratchit family drew round the hearth, in what Bob Cratchit called a circle, meaning half a one; and at Bob Cratchit’s elbow stood the family display of glass. Two tumblers, and a custard-cup without a handle.
These held the hot stuff from the jug, however, as well as golden goblets would have done; and Bob served it out with beaming looks, while the chestnuts on the fire sputtered and cracked noisily. Then Bob proposed:
“A Merry Christmas to us all, my dears. God bless us!”
Which all the family re-echoed.
“God bless us every one!” said Tiny Tim, the last of all.
He sat very close to his father’s side upon his little stool. Bob held his withered little hand in his, as if he loved the child, and wished to keep him by his side, and dreaded that he might be taken from him.
“Spirit,” said Scrooge, with an interest he had never felt before, “tell me if Tiny Tim will live.”
“I see a vacant seat,” replied the Ghost, “in the poor chimney-corner, and a crutch without an owner, carefully preserved. If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, the child will die.”
“No, no,” said Scrooge. “Oh, no, kind Spirit! say he will be spared.”
“If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, none other of my race,” returned the Ghost, “will find him here. What then? If he be like to die, he had better do it, and decrease the surplus population.”
Scrooge hung his head to hear his own words quoted by the Spirit, and was overcome with penitence and grief.
“Man,” said the Ghost, “if man you be in heart, not adamant, forbear that wicked cant until you have discovered What the surplus is, and Where it is. Will you decide what men shall live, what men shall die? It may be, that in the sight of Heaven, you are more worthless and less fit to live than millions like this poor man’s child. Oh God! to hear the Insect on the leaf pronouncing on the too much life among his hungry brothers in the dust!”

Mrs. Cratchit heated the gravy, Peter mashed the potatoes with astonishing vigor, Belinda sweetened the applesauce, Martha dusted the hot plates, Bob took Tiny Tim beside him in a tiny corner at the table, and the two young Cratchits set chairs for everybody, not forgetting themselves, and mounting guard upon their posts, crammed spoons into their mouths, lest they should shriek for goose before their turn came to be helped. At last the dishes were set on, and grace was said. It was succeeded by a breathless pause, as Mrs. Cratchit, looking slowly all along the carving-knife, prepared to plunge it in the breast; but when she did, and when the long expected gush of stuffing issued forth, one murmur of delight arose all round the board, and even Tiny Tim, excited by the two young Cratchits, beat on the table with the handle of his knife, and feebly cried Hurrah! There never was such a goose. Bob said he didn’t believe there ever was such a goose cooked. Its tenderness and flavor, size and cheapness, were the themes of universal admiration. Eked out by apple-sauce and mashed potatoes, it was a sufficient dinner for the whole family; indeed, as Mrs. Cratchit said with great delight (surveying one small atom of a bone upon the dish), they hadn’t ate it all at last! Yet every one had had enough, and the youngest Cratchits in particular, were steeped in sage and onion to the eyebrows! But now, the plates being changed by Miss Belinda, Mrs. Cratchit left the room alone—too nervous to bear witnesses—to take the pudding up and bring it in. Suppose it should not be done enough! Suppose it should break in turning out! Suppose somebody should have got over the wall of the back-yard, and stolen it, while they were merry with the goose—a supposition at which the two young Cratchits became livid! All sorts of horrors were supposed. Hallo! A great deal of steam! The pudding was out of the copper. A smell like a washing-day! That was the cloth. A smell like an eating-house and a pastrycook’s next door to each other, with a laundress’s next door to that! That was the pudding! In half a minute Mrs. Cratchit entered—flushed, but smiling proudly—with the pudding, like a speckled cannon-ball, so hard and firm, blazing in half of half-a-quartern of ignited brandy, and bedight with Christmas holly stuck into the top. Oh, a wonderful pudding! Bob Cratchit said, and calmly too, that he regarded it as the greatest success achieved by Mrs. Cratchit since their marriage. Mrs. Cratchit said that now the weight was off her mind, she would confess she had had her doubts about the quantity of flour. Everybody had something to say about it, but nobody said or thought it was at all a small pudding for a large family. It would have been flat heresy to do so. Any Cratchit would have blushed to hint at such a thing. At last the dinner was all done, the cloth was cleared, the hearth swept, and the fire made up. The compound in the jug being tasted, and considered perfect, apples and oranges were put upon the table, and a shovel-full of chestnuts on the fire. Then all the Cratchit family drew round the hearth, in what Bob Cratchit called a circle, meaning half a one; and at Bob Cratchit’s elbow stood the family display of glass. Two tumblers, and a custard-cup without a handle. These held the hot stuff from the jug, however, as well as golden goblets would have done; and Bob served it out with beaming looks, while the chestnuts on the fire sputtered and cracked noisily. Then Bob proposed: 'A Merry Christmas to us all, my dears. God bless us!' Which all the family re-echoed. 'God bless us every one!' said Tiny Tim, the last of all. He sat very close to his father’s side upon his little stool. Bob held his withered little hand in his, as if he loved the child, and wished to keep him by his side, and dreaded that he might be taken from him. 'Spirit,' said Scrooge, with an interest he had never felt before, 'tell me if Tiny Tim will live.' 'I see a vacant seat,' replied the Ghost, 'in the poor chimney-corner, and a crutch without an owner, carefully preserved. If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, the child will die.' 'No, no,' said Scrooge. 'Oh, no, kind Spirit! say he will be spared.' 'If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, none other of my race,' returned the Ghost, 'will find him here. What then? If he be like to die, he had better do it, and decrease the surplus population.' Scrooge hung his head to hear his own words quoted by the Spirit, and was overcome with penitence and grief. 'Man,' said the Ghost, 'if man you be in heart, not adamant, forbear that wicked cant until you have discovered What the surplus is, and Where it is. Will you decide what men shall live, what men shall die? It may be, that in the sight of Heaven, you are more worthless and less fit to live than millions like this poor man’s child. Oh God! to hear the Insect on the leaf pronouncing on the too much life among his hungry brothers in the dust!'"

Mrs. Cratchit, her face flushed from the heat of the oven, beamed with pride as she carried it to the table, its savory aroma filling the cramped little room. The children, wide-eyed and scarcely able to contain their excitement, crowded around, their mouths watering at the sight of it. "Aye," murmured Bob, his eyes twinkling. "He has given us more than a dinner—he has given us joy."  

And joy there was, in abundance. Tiny Tim, propped up in his little chair at the corner of the table, clapped his thin hands together and declared it the finest goose he had ever seen—though, in truth, he had seen precious few in his short life. His brothers and sisters, Martha and Peter and the two young Cratchits whose names I cannot recall, laughed and chattered like sparrows, their faces alight with anticipation.  

The carving commenced with great ceremony. Bob, though no expert in such matters, performed his office with all the gravity of a lord mayor presiding over a feast. The knife slid through the crisp skin, releasing a burst of steam, and the rich juices pooled upon the platter. Mrs. Cratchit, ever vigilant, supervised the distribution of the portions, ensuring that none received too little—or, heaven forbid, too much.  

"Apple-sauce, Martha?" she inquired, as if it were the rarest delicacy in all of London.  

"Oh, yes, please!" Martha replied, her eyes shining.  

And so it went, each dish passed with reverence, each bite savored as though it might be their last. The potatoes, roasted to perfection, crumbled at the touch of a fork. The gravy, thick and fragrant, was ladled with a generous hand. Even the humble bread, usually so plain, seemed to take on a new dignity beside such a feast.  

But it was not merely the food that made the meal so extraordinary—it was the love that seasoned it. The Cratchits, poor as they were, possessed a wealth of affection that no miser’s gold could ever buy. Their laughter was genuine, their kindness unfeigned, and their gratitude as warm as the fire that crackled in the grate.  

As the last crumbs were cleared away and the final drops of gravy sopped up with crusts of bread, Bob raised his glass—a modest vessel, filled with a modest ale—and proposed a toast.  

"To Mr. Scrooge," he said, his voice thick with emotion. "May his heart be as light as ours this day, and may he never want for happiness."  

"Amen!" cried Tiny Tim, his small voice ringing clear above the rest.  

And in that moment, though the wind howled outside and the snow drifted against the windowpanes, the Cratchit household was as snug and merry as any palace in the land. events.text_segment:
Scrooge bent before the Ghost’s rebuke, and trembling cast his eyes upon the ground. But he raised them speedily, on hearing his own name.
“Mr. Scrooge!” said Bob; “I’ll give you Mr. Scrooge, the Founder of the Feast!”
“The Founder of the Feast indeed!” cried Mrs. Cratchit, reddening. “I wish I had him here. I’d give him a piece of my mind to feast upon, and I hope he’d have a good appetite for it.”
“My dear,” said Bob, “the children! Christmas Day.”
“It should be Christmas Day, I am sure,” said she, “on which one drinks the health of such an odious, stingy, hard, unfeeling man as Mr. Scrooge. You know he is, Robert! Nobody knows it better than you do, poor fellow!”
“My dear,” was Bob’s mild answer, “Christmas Day.”
“I’ll drink his health for your sake and the Day’s,” said Mrs. Cratchit, “not for his. Long life to him! A merry Christmas and a happy new year! He’ll be very merry and very happy, I have no doubt!”
The children drank the toast after her. It was the first of their proceedings which had no heartiness. Tiny Tim drank it last of all, but he didn’t care twopence for it. Scrooge was the Ogre of the family. The mention of his name cast a dark shadow on the party, which was not dispelled for full five minutes.
After it had passed away, they were ten times merrier than before, from the mere relief of Scrooge the Baleful being done with. Bob Cratchit told them how he had a situation in his eye for Master Peter, which would bring in, if obtained, full five-and-sixpence weekly. The two young Cratchits laughed tremendously at the idea of Peter’s being a man of business; and Peter himself looked thoughtfully at the fire from between his collars, as if he were deliberating what particular investments he should favour when he came into the receipt of that bewildering income. Martha, who was a poor apprentice at a milliner’s, then told them what kind of work she had to do, and how many hours she worked at a stretch, and how she meant to lie abed to-morrow morning for a good long rest; to-morrow being a holiday she passed at home. Also how she had seen a countess and a lord some days before, and how the lord “was much about as tall as Peter;” at which Peter pulled up his collars so high that you couldn’t have seen his head if you had been there. All this time the chestnuts and the jug went round and round; and by-and-bye they had a song, about a lost child travelling in the snow, from Tiny Tim, who had a plaintive little voice, and sang it very well indeed.
There was nothing of high mark in this. They were not a handsome family; they were not well dressed; their shoes were far from being water-proof; their clothes were scanty; and Peter might have known, and very likely did, the inside of a pawnbroker’s. But, they were happy, grateful, pleased with one another, and contented with the time; and when they faded, and looked happier yet in the bright sprinklings of the Spirit’s torch at parting, Scrooge had his eye upon them, and especially on Tiny Tim, until the last.

Scrooge bent before the Ghost’s rebuke, and trembling cast his eyes upon the ground. The weight of his past misdeeds pressed upon him like a crushing stone, and for the first time in many years, he felt the sting of remorse. The Spirit’s words had pierced his hardened heart, and though he wished to defend himself, no excuse would come to his lips.  

The Ghost of Christmas Present, majestic yet stern, regarded him with a gaze that seemed to see into the very depths of his soul. “Hear me, Ebenezer Scrooge,” the Spirit intoned, his voice resonating like distant thunder. “The world is filled with suffering, and yet you have turned your back upon it. You have hoarded your wealth while others starved, shuttered your heart while others wept. Is this the legacy you wish to leave behind?”  

Scrooge could not answer. His mind raced with images of the poor Cratchit family, of Tiny Tim’s frail form, of the countless faces he had ignored in the streets. He had told himself that their struggles were none of his concern, that poverty was the natural order of things. But now, confronted by the Spirit’s unwavering judgment, he saw the cruelty of his indifference.  

“I… I did not know,” Scrooge stammered at last, though the words sounded feeble even to his own ears.  

“Did not know?” the Ghost repeated, his voice thick with disbelief. “Or did not care to know? The truth has always been before you, Ebenezer, if only you had chosen to see it.”  

A great shudder passed through Scrooge, and he clutched at his chest as if his heart might burst. The weight of his selfishness bore down upon him, and he feared he might be crushed beneath it. Yet even in his despair, a flicker of something unfamiliar stirred within him—a longing, faint but growing, to make amends.  

The Ghost’s expression softened slightly, as if sensing the shift in Scrooge’s spirit. “It is not too late,” he said, his voice now gentler. “The future is not yet written. But you must choose, and choose quickly, whether to cling to your old ways or embrace the chance for redemption.”  

Scrooge lifted his gaze, his eyes wet with unshed tears. “Tell me what I must do,” he pleaded.  

The Ghost extended a hand, and before them appeared a vision—a bustling street filled with people, laughter mingling with the strains of carols. Among them, Scrooge saw himself, but not as he was now. This other Scrooge smiled warmly, pressed coins into the hands of beggars, and clasped the arms of friends. The sight was so foreign, so impossible, that Scrooge could scarcely believe it.  

“Is this… could this truly be?” he whispered.  

“It can,” the Ghost replied. “But only if you will it so.”  

For a long moment, Scrooge stood in silence, his mind reeling. Then, with a resolve he had not felt in decades, he straightened his shoulders and met the Spirit’s gaze. “I will change,” he declared, his voice steady. “I swear it.”  

The Ghost nodded, and a faint smile touched his lips. “Then let us see if your actions match your words.” With that, the Spirit raised his torch, and the scene dissolved into swirling mist, carrying Scrooge forward into the unknown—toward a future he now dared to hope might be different.

events.title: Wider Christmas Travels and Visit to Fred's Party
detailed_summary: As night deepens and snow falls heavily, Scrooge and the Spirit travel onward, observing the cheerful glow from countless homes.
They see preparations for cozy dinners, families reuniting joyfully in the snow, guests arriving for parties, and groups of young women heading to neighbours' houses.
The narrator notes the vast number of people heading to gatherings, implying every house is expecting company.
The Ghost visibly exults, floating along and generously spreading bright, harmless mirth everywhere.
Even the lamplighter, unaware of their presence, laughs aloud as the Spirit passes.
Without warning, they are transported to a desolate, frozen moor.
The Spirit explains it's a place where miners live, but assures Scrooge, 'they know me.'
They approach a hut from which light shines and pass through the wall to find a cheerful, multi-generational family gathered around a fire, singing Christmas carols.
The Spirit doesn't linger, bidding Scrooge hold his robe again.
They travel over the moor and then out to sea, to Scrooge's horror.
They arrive at a solitary lighthouse on a dismal reef, where two keepers share a Christmas toast over grog and sing a hearty song.
The Ghost speeds onward again, over the dark sea, eventually landing on a ship far from shore.
